Art. 4.48. 
Concealment and forfeiture of the right to renounce 
An heir or successor who, in bad faith, conceals information or makes false declarations concerning the composition or extent of the succession, in order to obtain an advantage for himself to the detriment of his coheirs or the creditors of the succession, is guilty of concealment.
An heir or successor who is guilty of receiving stolen goods forfeits the right to renounce the succession. Even if they wished to renounce the succession, they remain heirs pure and simple, without being able to claim any share in the property or assets concealed.
This penalty may not be invoked against an heir or successor who spontaneously and in good time provides accurate and complete information or rectifies false declarations.
